segments.text: The principal job I did when I was in that position is all right now.
You bet.
This was nothing to do with the interior of the United States at all.
It was the problem of waterlogging and salinity in the irrigated areas of West Pakistan.
On the partition of India into two countries, most of the irrigated area, most of the well irrigated area, went to Pakistan.
This was in the Punjab, the western part of the Punjab, the part that went to Pakistan.
and in the Sindh, which is a province of Pakistan just south of Punjab.

For 100 years, the British have been developing a vast irrigation system in this area, using the waters from the five tributaries of the Punjab, the Jhelum, the Chinab, the Ravi, the Sudluj, and the Beas.
The word Punjab means five rivers, Punjab.
The same word as Pentagon, Pentagon, or Pentathlon.
These are all the tributaries of the Indus River, which is the great river that rises in the Himalayas and flows west and into the Arabian Sea.

Geologically, it's the whole Indo-Gangetic plain, the plain from the Indus all the way to the Bay of Bengal is one geological phenomenon formed by the crushing of the Indian subcontinent as it moved north across the Indian Ocean and came up against the continent of Asia, pushed up the Himalayas and pushed down this huge trough.
And during a good part of the last few million years,
The waters of that, most of that plain flowed westward into the Arabian Sea.
Now most of the water flows east into the Bengal.
That's the Ganges River.
But a very large, about a third of the water flows southwest into the Arabian Sea in the Indus River and its tributaries.
The British have built what are called barrages across the
the tributaries of the Indus and across the Indus itself.

The biggest barrage in the world, the biggest single irrigation system in the world is the Great Sucker Barrage, which diverts the Indus River into four different, four or five different huge canals in the same.
There were lots of other rivers and lots of other barrages.
Next to each barrage were huge irrigation canals, which carried water over what were called doabs, that is, the areas between two of the tributaries.
For example, the Upper Berry Doab Canal came off the Ravi River and irrigated the area between the Ravi and the
There was a canal that did the same thing.
It came off the and irrigated what was called between the and the and so forth.
Altogether, about 25 million acres of irrigated land.
That's more than the total of irrigated land in the United States.
It's all one big system.
And after partition, the Indians felt very much aggrieved because the waters of these tributaries arise in India, in Kashmir.
One of the substantive issues in the dispute about Kashmir was the river waters.
Finally, about 1960,
The dispute was settled by something called the Indus Waters Treaty, which provided that the waters of the three eastern tributaries, the Bayas, the Sudluja, and the Ravi, would go to India.
And the waters of the three western rivers, the Indus, the Jhelum, and the Chunab, would go to Pakistan.
This averted a war between the two countries.
And the price for averting that war

an enormous change in the irrigation works so that the water from the western rivers could be diverted to irrigate the part of Pakistan which had previously been irrigated from the Ravi and the Sudnuj.
And this consisted of the building of a great link canal between the rivers and siphons and dams.
Two big dams were contemplated, the Mangladama Dam on the Jhelum
Tarbella Dam on the Indus.
And these are just about the largest dams in the world, although they don't hold very much water.
They hold about 10 million acre feet of water at most, whereas the Glen Canyon Dam holds about 100 million acre feet of water on the Colorado River.
As part of this project,

something was felt that something also had to be done to provide drainage for the irrigated system because something was happening which always happened in the irrigation system without drainage, and that is that salt was accumulating in the soil and water, the water table rose, had risen to the point where there were
The low-lying areas were what are called waterlogged.
Water was actually standing at the surface.
By far, the most serious of these two things was the accumulation of salt.
And the way we got involved with it was that you may remember in 1961, President Kennedy decreed that we would not provide any more arms to Pakistan.
President Ayyub came over here and made an impassioned speech to Congress about this.
And he was quite popular in Congress.
He was a very impressive man.
He was a big man with a baton.
He looked like an English general, talked like an English general, and behaved like an English general.
But a very intelligent general, not a stupid one by any means.
Very appealing guy.
Kennedy felt that he had to do something for Pakistan.
And it previously had been worked out by Wiesner and by Abdus Salam, who was a science advisor to Ayub.
He's a Pakistani physicist, a professor at the University of London, that Ayub would suggest that we try to work on this problem of waterlogging and salinity.
a very distressing and well-publicized problem in Pakistan.
And Kennedy said, that's just the kind of problem my science advises himself.
Jerry knew nothing whatever about waterlogging and salinity.
And so he called on me to get involved with it.
I didn't know anything about waterlogging and salinity either, but I'm an oceanographer, and I'm supposed to know something about salt.
So I organized a task force panel.
It was called the White House Interior Panel on Water Logging and Salinity in West Pakistan.
And this was a, I didn't know quite who to get on the panel, but I got a lot of help from a lot of people, including a group of guys at Harvard.
Harvey Brooks was at that time.
Weisner's deputy and the vice chairman of PSAC, Resident Science Advisory Committee.
And he and I were old friends.

And he said that there was a group at Harvard who had been working on problems of water resources development, particularly an economist named Bob Dorfman and an engineer named Harold Thomas and their students.
And we put them on the panel.
A group of us, a group of the panel members, one of the other panel members was Rollin Eckes, who was that time president of Richfield Oil Company, an old friend of mine.
Another was Wadley, who was agronomist, senior agronomist at the USDA.
Another was a man from the
from the AID.
He was a specialist in administration.
His name was Blanford, John Blanford.
And we had the head of the salinity laboratory at Riverside, Charlie Bower, and one of his good men.
We got a bunch of idea men, goody men named Leonard Katz, who was an entrepreneur and inventor in Cambridge.
John Isaacs, who was an idea man here at Scripps.
And this group went out to Pakistan and looked at the Punjab and at the Sindh, made a trip across country, driving across country.
And I never will forget the day that Charlie Bower looked at a corn plant.
looked at the leaves of the corn plant and said, the problem with this corn is not that it's got too much salt in the soil, but there isn't any nitrogen in the soil.
This plant is lacking in chlorophyll because it has insufficient nitrogen.
And that was the payoff to the whole problem.
Water logging and salinity was, in a sense, a non-problem.
The real problem was poor agricultural practice.
The irrigation system had been started in the middle of the 19th century and long before irrigation or agriculture or high-yielding agriculture was well understood.
And they were spreading water too thin on too much land.
So the plants were starved with water as well as being starved with nutrients.
And the reason that they've done that was that they were trying to develop subsistence agriculture.
And subsistence agriculture depends on every farmer having as much land as he can cultivate.
Well, they spread out over a lot of land and didn't give enough water to any of it.
But at the same time, the canals leaked, and the whole canal system leaked.
About 40% of the water went down to the underground.
So this represented an enormous additional water supply, which could be pumped out and used for irrigation.
And it was by far the best way to store the water.
Storing it underground doesn't evaporate very much.
It evaporated some when you got the water table close to the surface.
And that evaporation was what caused the salt to accumulate at the surface.
And the salt problem didn't certainly look bad.
The English, in their systematic way, had established villages in all these dohabs on a two-mile grid, two-mile squares, village every two miles.
And there were large areas where these villages had disappeared or half disappeared, where the ground had become covered with salt, and the farmers had to abandon agriculture.
Pakistanis thought they were losing about 50,000 acres a year to salt accumulation.
And maybe they were.
The solution, the technical solution, was to drill what are called tube wells, which are big wells that are powered by machinery, by motors, either electric or diesel.
Either electric motors or diesel engines.
and to pump out the water, and thereby to lower the water table, and then use the water that you pumped out for irrigation and use enough water so some of it ran back down into the ground.
And in the process of doing that, you could wash the salt out of the salt back into the underground.
And this is not a permanent solution, but it's a solution that will do very well for 20 to 30 years.
On a permanent basis, you have to build horizontal drains, that is, drains that will actually carry as much salt out of the region as is coming into the region from the rivers.
That's not very much, actually.
Only rivers are remarkably fresh.
But they do have about 200 parts per million of salt.
That's quite a bit of salt year after year.
And you've just got to get rid of that salt by carrying it away, even to the Arabian Sea or to the Rajasthan desert.
That's not been done yet.
But this vertical drainage that we recommended was well known.
And if you do it in the way that we recommended, you can actually lower the water table, eliminate water logging, wash the salt down, and reclaim the land.
But more importantly, you've got a lot more water.
About 35% or 40% more water.
And this was on a very big scale.
The total water supply, including the underground water, about 100 million acre feet.
That's enough to irrigate 25 million acres to a depth of four feet.
If it all gets on the irrigated fields, it doesn't either evaporate or sink into the ground.
If it sinks into the ground, you can reclaim it.
Pump it up and use it.
And that's where this 100 million acre feet thing comes from.
But the problem was that this vertical drainage had been tried on too small a scale.
They put in a few wells, and underground water would flow in from the side as fast as you pumped it out.
As a result, they were not able to lower the water table.
And we did a lot of the, Harold Thomas and also a guy named Herb Skibitsky of the Geological Survey made models of the underground flow.
both digital, computer, and analog models.
And we showed that you had to put wells in an area as big as somewhere between 100,000 and a million acres, or it wouldn't work.
You had to drain a large area.
So you could drain it, pump it out faster than the water was flowing from the side.
And that depends on the ratio between area and perimeter.
You can see if you have .
well field in an area of one square mile, you've got four miles of perimeter in one mile of area.
In that case, the water flows in from the side as fast as you pump it out.
Let's say you have instead of one square mile, you have 1,600 square miles.
Then you have an area of 40 miles on the side, or 160 miles.
perimeter for 1,600 square miles of area, in contrast to the other extreme where I said there were four miles of perimeter for one square mile of area.
And if you use a scale like that, then there's no problem about pumping it out.
And that's what we were able to show with our models.
But far more important than that was that this was really not a problem.
of water logging and salinity, but a problem of improving agricultural technology, modernizing the agriculture.
And that's meant using fertilizer.
It meant using high-yielding varieties, which were just appearing in Mexico at that time.
It meant using pesticides.
It meant giving instruction and extension services to the farmers.
making it worthwhile for the farmers to increase their yields by stabilizing prices and things like that.
And we said, and this is the most important thing we said, was that this was one of the great natural resources of the Earth.
And it could be a garden.
It could be like the Imperial Valley.
But instead of 500,000 acres like the Imperial Valley, it had 25 million acres, 50 times the size of the Imperial Valley.
This was really a revolutionary idea to the bureaucrats who were running Pakistan.
One of my best friends became a man named Gul Amishat Khan, who was chairman of the Water and Power Development Authority of West Pakistan.
He was a member of the elite civil service of Pakistan.
and CSP, a remarkably able man.
He had about as high an IQ as I'd ever seen on anybody.
He could handle about a dozen of us who were on one side of the table.
He was on the other all by himself with no problem.
He was just so darned competent and so knowledgeable and so intelligently able to grasp new ideas.
And what we proposed was, and this was a mistake, but it was a mistake that everybody had made, who we went along with, that the government should do this job in million-acre tracks.
That means a track 1,600 miles an area.
And there would be 25 of these tracks, and they should go after one after the other in succession.
On the theory that that was about all we could do to really
introduce modernized agriculture.
Maybe they could do one a year or something like that on a 25-year program.
Wilhelmi Schock objected to this, and rightly so, on the basis that politically this was impossible.
You had to give some benefit to everybody.
But the solution, the problem was really solved in spite of both of us by the farmers of Papastop.
When they found out about these two wells,
to drill them all by themselves.
And they drilled something like 70,000 tube wells in three years, while the government was drilling about 2,000.
And what none of us had realized was that these farmers were very responsive to change if they could really see the benefits of the change.
And I have a saying, which I often use,
There's no change agent quite as effective as an Indian or a Pakistani farmer in hot pursuit of a rupee.
It was just fantastic what these people did.
And within a few years, agricultural production in Pakistan was increasing by about 6% a year, about twice as fast as the population.
And the new seeds came in, and the fertilizer came in, and the water.
and they developed the water, and all of this was really quite a spectacular change.
I was back in Pakistan last summer, and agriculture is stagnant in Pakistan at the moment.
It's not growing.
And one of the things I'm very puzzled about is, why is this so?
Pakistanis have their old complaint that we need more water and we need more drainage.
I don't really think that's the problem.
I think the problem is the economic and social structure of the country, which essentially puts agriculture at the lowest possible priority.
And the second problem is that most of the land that could now be increasing its production is in quite small farms, farms that are about five acres or less.
And if you look at the economics of it, small farmers like that don't really have much incentive to increase their production.
They just can't make enough profit.
You need to find ways in which you develop a farming system for small farmers.
This is a social, economic, political, technical complex of problems, which is not very well understood by anybody.
And that's the next big step that needs to be undertaken.
I'm going to try to go back to Pakistan this summer and look into this much more thoroughly than I have been able to up until now.
But at least for up until about 1968 or 69, agriculture looked like a great success story in Pakistan.
It was being modernized.
And the report that we wrote, we called it Land and Water Development in this Plain.
became a kind of a bible called the Revelle Report.

It was superseded by a very much more elaborate World Bank study, which was published about 1969 or 70, but which essentially came to exactly the same conclusions that we do in terms of the possibilities for development, but laying much more stress, as they should, on the farmers themselves and helping the farmers help themselves.
And of course, in the process of writing this report, I didn't get it done until 1963, long after I'd left the Department of the Interior and gone back to University of California.
I got to be very good friends with people at Harvard, particularly Dorfman and Thomas and Bob Burden.
One or two other people there.
And they were about, at that time, they were about to, they'd been planning to organize a center for population studies at Harvard.
And Harold Thomas suggested my name for the directorship of it.
I was really quite unhappy out here.
I had two jobs here, and this was impossible.
I was director of the Scripps Institution and also university dean of research at the same time.
University dean of research turned out to be a non-job.
Nobody with nobody needed a university dean of research.
Professors just don't like to have anybody tell them about what they should do in the research business.
At the same time, I was really neglecting the Scripps Institution.
And Herb York had resigned as chancellor.
And it turned out that they didn't want me to be chancellor.
So I decided I'd go back to Harvard and become head of the Center for Population Studies, which I started, actually, in 1964.
which I've just this past summer retired from.
But basically because of my interest in resources, the center has always concentrated more on matching resources to population rather than thinking about how you reduce population.
In other words, we've thought about that too a lot, but we've thought
in terms of economic and social development rather than in terms of family planning programs.
This was not really a way to win friends and influence people among the population establishment.
They were all hooked on family planning.
And moreover, they're not really much interested in development, but the kind of people who support
population center to people like Cordelia Scaife May of the Mellon family in Pittsburgh, who basically believes there are too many niggers in the world.
And is much more concerned about the damage to the environment than she is about people.
And these are these fanatics on the right wing of the population.
say that the world is going to hell because of overpopulation.
It isn't going to hell because of overpopulation.
It may be going to hell, but for other reasons.
But our feeling was and is that rapid population growth, which is the real problem more than overpopulation, rapid population growth is as much a symptom of poverty as it is a cause of poverty.
And what really needs to be done is to do something about poverty.

So one of our big projects at the center is a Ford Foundation-supported project for systematic analysis and modeling of resources development in the Indian subcontinent, particularly agricultural, water, and land development.
And we've been working particularly on the Ganges plain the last few years.
Before that, we worked on Bangladesh,
where we're going to expand it to include Sri Lanka and Nepal and Pakistan.

That's under the direction of one of Harold Thomas's students, who's now become a professor named Peter Rogers, who is one of the young men that worked on our, at that time, graduate students that worked on our Indus Basin program with Harold.
And I'm going back this fall.
primarily to work with Peter and help out with this board foundation project.

What it consists of is that we bring Indian engineers and economists and government officials to Cambridge in a period of six months to a year and have them do research on problems of agricultural land and water development.
